title: Platform Revolution
description: Uber. Airbnb. Amazon. Apple. PayPal. All of these companies disrupted their markets when they launched. Today they are industry leaders. What's the secret to their success? These cutting-edge businesses are built on platforms: two-sided markets that are revolutionising the way we do business.
author: Geoffrey G Parker

title: Applied Artificial Intelligence
description: Artificial intelligence is the buzzword of the day. You've no doubt read your fair share of media hype either proclaiming doom and gloom where robots seize our jobs or prophesying a new utopia where AI cures all our human problems.

title: Design of Business
description: Most companies today have innovation envy. They yearn to come up with a game—changing innovation like Apple's iPod, or create an entirely new category like Facebook.

title: Playing to Win
description: Strategy is not complex. But it is hard. It’s hard because it forces people and organizations to make specific choices about their future—something that doesn’t happen in most companies.

title: Your Strategy Needs a Strategy
description: Executives are bombarded with bestselling ideas and best practices for achieving competitive advantage, but many of these ideas and practices contradict each other.

title: Strategy That Works
description: Two-thirds of executives say their organizations don’t have the capabilities to support their strategy. In Strategy That Works, Paul Leinwand and Cesare Mainardi explain why.

title: Fintech in a Flash
description: Welcome to the exciting world of Fintech! The financial services technology industry is booming, with investment in excess of $20 billion just in the last year.

title: Swipe to Unlock
description: Authored by Product Managers at Google, Microsoft, and Facebook, Swipe to Unlock is a guide which enables anyone to understand the core concepts of tech and the business strategy behind it.

title: The Product Book
description: No one asked you to show up. Every experienced product manager has heard some version of those words at some point in their career. Think about a company.
